A Doubtful Issue
In theory the Gentlemen's Code Commission is a
sorely wanted adjunct to student government on this
campus. In our editorial of May 12, we pointed out that
there are many valid reasons for instituting such a body
at Homewood. The legislative and judicial functions of
the student government should be separated, and this
judicial function should be integrated into a single body
with jurisdiction over the entire campus. Moreover, as
has been apparent for several years, there must be distinct and equitable rules of conduct for all judicial
proceedings.
_ However, this is not to say that the proposed Gentlemen's Code Commission is an entirely adequate document. While this amendment does contain several
needed provisions designed to correct the shortcomings
of our present system, it also endangers the very basis of
undergraduate life at Hopkins—the Gentlemen's Code.
For this Commission to function, the Student Council must first legislate into existence a whole series of
regulations and penalties. It is obvious that this necessary
enactment of a judicial code is a negation of the Gentlemen's Code, which the Commission is, ironically, designed to protect.
If the Student Council is especially prudent in passing this legislation, and if the Commission itself rightly
interprets the Gentlemen's Code, then the prized and
desired freedom of the undergraduate can be maintained.
If this is not the case, then the Gentlemen's Code will
become a meaningless piece of paper.
The student body should carefully weigh both the
advantages and the disadvantages of the Gentlemen's
Code Commission before voting on the issue next meek.
No one has yet been able to give a complete solution to
the problem, and it might be hoped that the Commission
is an improvement on the existing situation. However, in
the last analysis the decision is the student's, and he alone
can make it.

Welcome, Norman Thomas
Discoursing editorially upon the occasion of Norman
Thomas' seventy-fifth birthday, The New York Times
said, "In six Presidential campaigns it has been possible
for American voters who didn't like either of the major
candidates to cast their ballots for Norman Thomas. It
was a safe thing to do this, for they knew that Mr.
Thomas, who calls himself a Socialist, would not go to
the White House—except possibly for lunch. It was safe
in another way for no one quite lost his vote when he
gave it to a man so intelligent, so patriotic and so universally respected as Norman Matoon Thomas."
A man of seventy-seven years now, Mr. Thomas
has long given up running for political office. He remains both an admired and respected citizen as well
as eloquent testimony to the American right of dissent.
A Socialist since 1918, Mr. Thomas might today modify
some of the causes for which he has stood in the last
forty-five years. But few men, of whatever political or
economic coloring, can argue with the universality of
his doctrines. He would never relinquish his belief that
war and democracy cannot coexist, the pacifism which
led him to oppose conscription, or his dislike of any
kind of violence—including the type practiced by Moscow. Mr. Thomas is no Marxist, in any sense of the word.
Norman Thomas himself has written, "It is with
somewhat mixed emotions that I find myself classified
as a leading American dissenter. I am indeed proud and
happy to live in a country where the right to dissent is
embodied in the basic law. I wish it were more honored
in practice. It is a right essential to any concept of the
dignity and freedom of the individual; it is essential
to the search for truth in a world wherein no authority
is infallible."
Mr. Thomas' topic for his speech here at Johns
Hopkins is "Can We Win Peace?" Students may expect
to hear some unconventional thoughts on the relative
attitudes of Premier Khrushchev and the Pentagon toward disarmament. He believes the two systems, the
Russian and ours, might in time draw closer together,
thus eliminating the deadly struggle in which we are
now involved. Nevertheless he realizes that the United
States would take and hold the lead in the "enjoyment
of democracy and individual right."
We heartily concur with The Times in saying,
44... it is wonderful to have Mr. Thomas around—we
hope he will be here for long years to come."

By IRV NATHAN, Sports Editor
After this reporter had decided to call a spade a spade
and to refrain from the overabundance of euphemisms
that usually abound during a losing season, a mighty voice
of righteous indignation arose from the "hopeless hoopsters," There were rumors that letters would pour in to
protect their names, talents, and coach. Fortunately, the
cagers found a better outlet in which to vent their rage.
They decided to pour the ball through the hoops, rather
than venture into literary endeavors.
In its last two regular season encounters, the Jay five
hit for two season scoring highs, one in losing to Hampden-Sydney, 92-73, the other in downing Dickinson, 82-78,
in the campaign's finale. The momentum fortunately carried over into the Mason-Dixon Conference tournament as
the hardwooders won their first tourney game since 1954
in downing sluggish Baltimore University.
M-D Championships

In its thirteen Mason-Dixon tournaments, the Blue
Jays have made it past the first round five times and lost
in the championship finals twice to American University—
in 1945 and 1951. Over-all, the Jays have compiled a 7-14
record, including five straight losses prior to last week's
victory over the Bees.
Never Say Die

Another interesting historical fact is that last night's
opponent Randolph-Macon has never beaten Hopkins in
its thirteen tries since 1946. More important than the
results of last night's game is the praiseworthy fact that
Ross Sachs's quintet never said "die" and was still battling
to fatten up the win column after a clearly disappointing
season. It is an easy thing to give up after losing dismally throughout the course of a season. That the
hoopsters have not lost heart is evidenced by their recent
spirited play. One only hopes that next year sincere compliments can be elicited earlier in a winning season.
Unsung Heroes

No one notices them when they are there; it's when
they absent themslves that their worth becomes manifest.
Managers play a vital part in the functioning of any
athletic squad: they serve as a coach's right-hand man,
tabulate statistics, take charge of equipment, and do
sundry other vital, but unglorified tasks.
The job of manager is not particularly appealing to
me, though I will admit to once harboring a deep-seated
desire to be bat boy for the Orioles. For those, however,
who need the exercise (who doesn't?), and are not
physically capable of particpating on the team as players,
managing could prove a worthwhile endeavor. If you
have an altruistic nature and a longing for the smell of
the locker room, you might wander over to the gym and
offer your services. They will be readily appreciated.

A Doubtful Issue
In theory the Gentlemen's Code Commission is a
sorely wanted adjunct to student government on this
campus. In our editorial of May 12, we pointed out that
there are many valid reasons for instituting such a body
at Homewood. The legislative and judicial functions of
the student government should be separated, and this
judicial function should be integrated into a single body
with jurisdiction over the entire campus. Moreover, as
has been apparent for several years, there must be distinct and equitable rules of conduct for all judicial
proceedings.
_ However, this is not to say that the proposed Gentlemen's Code Commission is an entirely adequate document. While this amendment does contain several
needed provisions designed to correct the shortcomings
of our present system, it also endangers the very basis of
undergraduate life at Hopkins—the Gentlemen's Code.
For this Commission to function, the Student Council must first legislate into existence a whole series of
regulations and penalties. It is obvious that this necessary
enactment of a judicial code is a negation of the Gentlemen's Code, which the Commission is, ironically, designed to protect.
If the Student Council is especially prudent in passing this legislation, and if the Commission itself rightly
interprets the Gentlemen's Code, then the prized and
desired freedom of the undergraduate can be maintained.
If this is not the case, then the Gentlemen's Code will
become a meaningless piece of paper.
The student body should carefully weigh both the
advantages and the disadvantages of the Gentlemen's
Code Commission before voting on the issue next meek.
No one has yet been able to give a complete solution to
the problem, and it might be hoped that the Commission
is an improvement on the existing situation. However, in
the last analysis the decision is the student's, and he alone
can make it.

Welcome, Norman Thomas
Discoursing editorially upon the occasion of Norman
Thomas' seventy-fifth birthday, The New York Times
said, "In six Presidential campaigns it has been possible
for American voters who didn't like either of the major
candidates to cast their ballots for Norman Thomas. It
was a safe thing to do this, for they knew that Mr.
Thomas, who calls himself a Socialist, would not go to
the White House—except possibly for lunch. It was safe
in another way for no one quite lost his vote when he
gave it to a man so intelligent, so patriotic and so universally respected as Norman Matoon Thomas."
A man of seventy-seven years now, Mr. Thomas
has long given up running for political office. He remains both an admired and respected citizen as well
as eloquent testimony to the American right of dissent.
A Socialist since 1918, Mr. Thomas might today modify
some of the causes for which he has stood in the last
forty-five years. But few men, of whatever political or
economic coloring, can argue with the universality of
his doctrines. He would never relinquish his belief that
war and democracy cannot coexist, the pacifism which
led him to oppose conscription, or his dislike of any
kind of violence—including the type practiced by Moscow. Mr. Thomas is no Marxist, in any sense of the word.
Norman Thomas himself has written, "It is with
somewhat mixed emotions that I find myself classified
as a leading American dissenter. I am indeed proud and
happy to live in a country where the right to dissent is
embodied in the basic law. I wish it were more honored
in practice. It is a right essential to any concept of the
dignity and freedom of the individual; it is essential
to the search for truth in a world wherein no authority
is infallible."
Mr. Thomas' topic for his speech here at Johns
Hopkins is "Can We Win Peace?" Students may expect
to hear some unconventional thoughts on the relative
attitudes of Premier Khrushchev and the Pentagon toward disarmament. He believes the two systems, the
Russian and ours, might in time draw closer together,
thus eliminating the deadly struggle in which we are
now involved. Nevertheless he realizes that the United
States would take and hold the lead in the "enjoyment
of democracy and individual right."
We heartily concur with The Times in saying,
44... it is wonderful to have Mr. Thomas around—we
hope he will be here for long years to come."

'Better Late . . .
By IRV NATHAN, Sports Editor
After this reporter had decided to call a spade a spade
and to refrain from the overabundance of euphemisms
that usually abound during a losing season, a mighty voice
of righteous indignation arose from the "hopeless hoopsters," There were rumors that letters would pour in to
protect their names, talents, and coach. Fortunately, the
cagers found a better outlet in which to vent their rage.
They decided to pour the ball through the hoops, rather
than venture into literary endeavors.
In its last two regular season encounters, the Jay five
hit for two season scoring highs, one in losing to Hampden-Sydney, 92-73, the other in downing Dickinson, 82-78,
in the campaign's finale. The momentum fortunately carried over into the Mason-Dixon Conference tournament as
the hardwooders won their first tourney game since 1954
in downing sluggish Baltimore University.
M-D Championships

In its thirteen Mason-Dixon tournaments, the Blue
Jays have made it past the first round five times and lost
in the championship finals twice to American University—
in 1945 and 1951. Over-all, the Jays have compiled a 7-14
record, including five straight losses prior to last week's
victory over the Bees.
Never Say Die

Another interesting historical fact is that last night's
opponent Randolph-Macon has never beaten Hopkins in
its thirteen tries since 1946. More important than the
results of last night's game is the praiseworthy fact that
Ross Sachs's quintet never said "die" and was still battling
to fatten up the win column after a clearly disappointing
season. It is an easy thing to give up after losing dismally throughout the course of a season. That the
hoopsters have not lost heart is evidenced by their recent
spirited play. One only hopes that next year sincere compliments can be elicited earlier in a winning season.
Unsung Heroes

No one notices them when they are there; it's when
they absent themslves that their worth becomes manifest.
Managers play a vital part in the functioning of any
athletic squad: they serve as a coach's right-hand man,
tabulate statistics, take charge of equipment, and do
sundry other vital, but unglorified tasks.
The job of manager is not particularly appealing to
me, though I will admit to once harboring a deep-seated
desire to be bat boy for the Orioles. For those, however,
who need the exercise (who doesn't?), and are not
physically capable of particpating on the team as players,
managing could prove a worthwhile endeavor. If you
have an altruistic nature and a longing for the smell of
the locker room, you might wander over to the gym and
offer your services. They will be readily appreciated.
